question:
You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code you generate is executable for demonstration purposes.
Please help me implement the following requirement using code. Create using SVG code: an eye with liquid medicine drops falling from it, with matching colors.

checklist.title: Is the eye anatomical structure accurately represented in SVG?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the SVG code correctly depicts the eye's anatomical elements (sclera, iris, pupil, eyelids, tear ducts). Deduct 3 points if major anatomical structures are missing, 2 points if proportions are unrealistic. Full implementation with anatomical accuracy scores 10 points, basic implementation scores 5 points, and poor implementation scores 0 points.

checklist.title: Are the liquid medicine drops effectively animated?
checklist.description: Check if the animation shows drops forming, detaching, falling with gravity, and potentially splashing/dispersing. The animation should use appropriate SVG animation techniques (SMIL or CSS). Deduct 5 points if the animation is jerky or unrealistic, 3 points if timing feels unnatural. Full score requires physics-based movement with proper acceleration.

checklist.title: Is the color matching appropriate for the medical context?
checklist.description: Assess whether the colors used for the eye and medicine drops are appropriate (typically blue/green/purple for eye medication). Score 10 points for a cohesive, intentional color scheme that enhances the medical visualization, 5 points for basic appropriate colors, 0 points for jarring or unrealistic color combinations that detract from the medical context.

checklist.title: Is the SVG implementation technically sound?
checklist.description: Review the SVG code structure for proper use of paths, groups, gradients, and other SVG elements. Check for optimization of code (no redundant elements, appropriate use of transforms). Deduct 5 points for implementation that could be significantly optimized, 3 points if basic SVG principles are violated.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle different viewport sizes, browser compatibility, and provides fallbacks if needed. Code with strong robustness should adapt to different display contexts, giving 10 points. If the implementation breaks in common scenarios, give 5 points, and if major compatibility issues exist, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the visualization (e.g., 1. Interactive elements responding to user input 2. Realistic liquid physics simulation 3. Environmental reflections or lighting effects). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant SVG elements that could be grouped or reused 2. Visual elements unrelated to the eye/medicine drops context 3. Excessive effects that negatively impact performance or clarity. Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core visualization is obscured by redundant elements.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as grouping related SVG elements, using reusable components), code readability (meaningful ids/classes), and implementation efficiency. Deduct 5 points if the SVG structure is chaotic; deduct 5 points if the code is excessively verbose without comments; deduct 5 points if basic optimizations are missing. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper visual hierarchy and focus 3) Balanced proportions and composition. Deduct 3 points for each visual distraction, 5 points for poor fundamental design choices, and 5 points for lack of visual coherence. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the animation effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Smooth transitions without jank 2) Animation timing that feels natural and intentional 3) Appropriate easing functions for liquid movement. Deduct 5 points for jerky animations, 3 points for timing that feels unnatural, and 5 points for animations that disrupt the medical visualization context. The full score is 10 points.
